comment: Great professor with a vocation. Attendance is not mandatory and he explains topics very clear. Easy workload and open book tests. You will learn a lot from him as he does not just teaches just for teaching and he cares about his students.

Strength of Materials is a rough class, but Kaplan makes it manageable. There are fairly limited options at KSU, and I believe that he is probably the best. You will most likely fail the exams, but he provides a curve. As long as you do the homework you will make it out with at least a B.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: This guy is great to take. This class relies heavily on knowledge from statics, but you get a 2 week review. Drops the lowest test grade and the 2nd lowest can be replaced by final. Each test had a good curve including the final. Test questions come straight from the Hw and "worked problems." Gives like 10 homeworks that are due at the end of year
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Kaplan is one of the best professors at KSU. He genuinely cares about your understanding of the material and explains complex concepts with a clear and concise approach. He assigns homework relevant to what is covered in his lectures. Dr. Kaplan is incredibly sharp and fun to be around.

Dr. Kaplan's lectures were very interactive and educational! While Jeff Hanson on YT is your friend, Dr. Kaplan teaches very visually and a little different! He's a nice dude, and will curve your exams and final like CRAZY. Test problems are exactly from the Pearson hw, so if you do them before the test, you're solid. Fairly easy class!

Great professor for Statics. He very clearly explains concepts and does his best to answer all questions. Not a ton of homework and there are three tests with the lowest being dropped. Tests are also pretty easy and he curves grades.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: personally enjoyed his lecture style, he gives examples and explains how they work irl. however his exams consisted of harder concepts we didn't cover. his grading is skewed-this person makes the same mistake as that person, but they get more pts off. really harsh grader. only grades are 3 tests and about 6 HWs. claims his tests are "easy"-eye roll

Took him during the pandemic for advanced soil mechanics and he was absolutely terrible. Made us work with a software that he did not know how to use. Used easy examples in class but the homeworks and tests were way harder. Took forever to grade things. Very monotone. Seems like a nice guy, just a bad teacher.

Solid choice for strength of materials. Before the corona craziness, he originally does three exams one of which is dropped. He curves well. 15 for the first test and 20 for the second. Homework isnt bad. Also posts his lecture notes and videos online. Merciful grader as long as you make sense. Have an A right now and expect to make an A.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Avoid this professor, first test class average was 56 the test is completely different from the examples. Too hard. He takes about 3 weeks to grade a single test spends the entire class period on one example. Save your GPA avoid this professor.

Kaplan records all his lectures, is lenient grader, test are easy, he explains the concepts well, and home work is usually really helpful. Though the test are harder than the homework and he combines multiple concepts into one question so as long as you get the concepts you are fine. great professor i recommend highly
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures
